summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding scheduling of arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing in Maxwell's criminal case. The letter indicates Maxwell has waived her physical presence and proposes remote proceedings on July 14, 2020.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm Cohen & Gresser, currently held at the Metropolitan Detention Center, who has agreed to waive physical presence for upcoming court proceedings.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this scheduling letter is addressed.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who is representing Ghislaine Maxwell and signed this letter to the court regarding scheduling matters.

connections.description: Mark S. Cohen is submitting this letter on behalf of his client Ghislaine Maxwell, indicating he is her defense attorney.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Defense contacts Maxwell at detention center
events.description: Mark S. Cohen reports that he was able to speak with Ghislaine Maxwell for the first time at the Metropolitan Detention Center just before 9:00pm.

events.title: Proposed remote court proceedings
events.description: All parties agree to proceed remotely for arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing on this date.

events.title: Defense unavailable for proceedings
events.description: The defense indicates they will not be able to proceed with court proceedings on this date.

locations: United States Courthouse, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was in custody at the Metropolitan Detention Center as of July 6, 2020.
Maxwell waived her physical presence for upcoming arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing.
The defense and government agreed to proceed remotely on July 14, 2020, for court proceedings.
This document shows early procedural steps in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
